cards.front:
To protect vital organs, the body compensates by directing blood flow away from organs that are more tolerant of low flow, such as:

(See Pathophysiology)

A 20-year-old male has a large laceration to his wrist. He is holding a blood-soaked towel over the wound, but it continues to bleed rapidly. You should:

(See Emergency Medical Care for Shock)
cards.back: apply a tourniquet proximal to the wrist.

cards.front:
Hypovolemic shock caused by severe burns is the result of a loss of:

(See Types of Shock)

Shock is the result of:

(See Introduction)
cards.back: hypoperfusion to the cells of the body.

cards.front:
Which of the following clinical signs is unique to anaphylactic shock?

(See Types of Shock)

Which of the following statements regarding anaphylactic shock is correct?

(See Types of Shock)
cards.back: Subsequent exposure after sensitization often produces a more severe reaction.

cards.front:
All of the following conditions should make you suspect shock, EXCEPT:

(See The Progression of Shock)

Capillary sphincters are:

(See Pathophysiology)
cards.back: circular muscular walls that regulate blood flow through the capillaries.

cards.front:
Which of the following injuries would MOST likely cause obstructive shock?

(See Types of Shock)

Which of the following patients is in decompensated shock?

(See The Progression of Shock)
cards.back: A 20-year-old female with absent radial pulses and dilated pupils

cards.front:
Clinical signs of compensated shock include all of the following, EXCEPT:

(See The Progression of Shock)

A 70-year-old female was recently discharged from the hospital following a total hip replacement. Today, she presents with restlessness, tachycardia, and a blood pressure of 90/64 mm Hg. Her skin is hot and moist. You should be MOST suspicious that she is experiencing:

(See Types of Shock)

Pulmonary edema and impaired ventilation occur during:

(See Types of Shock)

In an acute injury setting, neurogenic shock is commonly accompanied by:

(See Types of Shock)

One of the primary waste products of normal cellular metabolism that must be removed from the body by the lungs is:

(See Pathophysiology)

Distributive shock occurs when:

(See Types of Shock)
cards.back: widespread dilation of the blood vessels causes blood to pool in the vascular beds.

cards.front:
Cardiogenic shock may result from all of the following, EXCEPT:

(See Types of Shock)

Which of the following would MOST likely result in hemorrhagic shock?

(See Types of Shock)

Which of the following is the ONLY action that can prevent death from a tension pneumothorax?

(See Emergency Medical Care for Shock)
cards.back: Decompression of the injured side of the chest

cards.front:
Neurogenic shock occurs when:

(See Types of Shock)
cards.back: failure of the nervous system causes widespread vasodilation.
